section.title: Achieve
section.para: This was created using the June 18, 2008 build of GMAT.

section.title: Overview
section.para: The purpose of the Achieve command is to define a goal for the spacecraft to reach at some point in its trajectory. The goal must have a corresponding value and tolerance so the differential corrector can solve for the best solution during the spacecraft's flight. To define a goal, a property must be chosen out of the Parameter Select dialog box along with the correct components in the other fields. The command can only be appended within a targeting sequence and must be accompanied and preceeded by a Vary, Maneuver, and Propagate command.

section.title: Listing of Objects and Commands that interact

listitem.para: Spacecraft
In order to achieve a goal at all, a spacecraft must exist so GMAT has something to propagate and maneuver.
Differential Corrector
A differential corrector is needed to calculate and solve for the goal to be achieved.
Vary Command

This command pulls variables into a targeting sequence for GMAT to know what parameters are being changed. As soon as a change occurs in a parameter, the differential corrector solves for the best trajectory using that data in order to achieve a goal.
Maneuver Command
Changing any parameter of the spacecraft requires a Maneuver command and some sort of burn, so this, too, is an essential part of the Achieve command
Burn
Changing parameters by means of maneuvering requires a burn to do so, and in this process the spacecraft is achieving a goal.
Propagate Command
To achieve a goal, the spacecraft must be moving and, thus, be executing a Propagate command.

section.title: Using the GUI
section.para: The Achieve command dialog box has four fields to consider including a drop down menu for the Solver. By clicking on the View buttons, parameters from the Parameter Select dialog box can be chosen and entered in as a goal. Once a legitimate value and tolerance are entered for the parameter, the command is complete and is ready to run in the mission.

listitem.para: Solver - Drop Down Menu
All of the differential correctors created are located in this menu to choose from for the Achieve command to utilize during operation.
Goal - Field

Choosing a goal requires an object, parameter, and potentially a coordinate system to be highlighted in the Parameter Select dialog box. Once all are selected, the field will read (spacecraft).(coordinate system).(parameter), depending on the need for a coordinate system. If a system is not required, the field will read (spacecraft).(parameter).
Value - Field

A number is to be entered here that corresponds to the goal chosen. If the value does not make sense, the mission will run, but it will not converge. Also, depending on the situation, excess data points may be created and will produce the same outcome.
Tolerance - Field
The tolerance tells GMAT how lenient the differential corrector should be when accepting solutions around the value entered in previous field.

info.title: Figure: Default Name and Settings for the Achieve Command Dialog Box

caption.para: Figure: Default Name and Settings for the Achieve Command Dialog Box

entry.para: The option allows the user to select any single element user defined parameter, except a number, to Achieve.
Options: { Real Number, Array element, Variable, or any user defined parameter that obeys the conditions of Chapter~\\ref\{Ch:ObjectsNResources\} for the selected }
The Arg1 option is the desired value for after the solver has converged.
The Tolerance option sets Arg2. Arg2 is the convergence tolerance for Arg1.
Options: { Any user defined differential corrector }
The SolverName option allows the user to choose which solver to assign to the Achieve command.
